title: Diploma in User Experience Design for the Web using Adobe XD
headline: Take your career to the next level with this free online course about UI/UX design using the Adobe XD platform.
description: This course is for those who want to start a career in User Experience (UX) design. It teaches you everything that you need to know, starting from scratch with Adobe XD basics to more advanced types of User Interfaces (UIs) and UI elements. Gain a wealth of knowledge, tips, tricks, tools, and resources to jumpstart your career. We will also cover project management, marketing and networking, building your website, logo, and brand.
courseDescription:
If you are artistically inclined and want to have a career in user experience design, you’re at the right place. This course will equip you with everything you need to kickstart your career as an expert UX/UI designer. You do not need any prior skills or knowledge of design or technology. All you need is Adobe XD installed on your computer. We’ll start with the basics and take you through the entire journey of becoming a professional in this exciting field. We will guide you in this journey through video lectures interspersed with Adobe XD lessons and a variety of demonstrations and useful links.

To begin with, you will learn about UX, UI, and the UX/UI designer marketplace. We will provide you with a fair idea of the roles you could expect to play in this marketplace and how best to perform in any of those roles. You will then become initiated in graphic design through the concepts of colours, fonts, icons, vector graphics, and software tools. Because UX design is all about users, you must understand your users and their pain points. You will learn all about user-profiles and user persona, customer journey through the user interfaces, sales funnel, and the concept of market sophistication. You will learn about storyboards, mood boards, wireframes, app architecture, and prototypes on the design front. You will also learn about different kinds of user interfaces and how to design their elements. If you follow the XD lessons closely, you will have hands-on training on using the various features of Adobe XD and creating UI layouts and elements yourself.

This well-rounded course also points out the good practices and resources that can help you start a freelancing or consulting career. We include step-by-step lessons to build your website from scratch, design your logo using free web resources, and create your brand. You will also obtain valuable tips on networking, getting client referrals, acquiring freelance assignments, and marketing. What more do you need than this comprehensive guide to secure a flying start to your UX/UI design career? You will learn all there is to know about carving out your UX career and be on your way to becoming an expert in this field. So, jump right in and start learning now!

Start Course Now
certificateDetail:
All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital : a downloadable in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • : a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked , posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed : a physical version of your officially branded and security marked in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.

All are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison , please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison , you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. For more details on our pricing, please visit our Pricing Page

• Learning Outcomes

  • After completing this module, you will be able to
    • Define UX and UI.
    • Describe the UX/UI Designer Marketplace.
    • Identify the different UX team roles.
    • Outline the responsibilities of a designer in a web development team.
    • List the stages of web development.
    • Distinguish between the traditional and the agile approach to project management.
    • Explain the concept of scrum.
    • Describe the Adobe XD interface.

  • Agile Approach To Project Management

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

  • Lesson Summary

    • UX design relies on visual strength, behavioural psychology and consumer research.
    • UX applies to anything that can be experienced.
    • UX professionals are united by their authentic interest in learning about people. 
    • User Interface(UI) is the look and feel, presentation and interactivity of a product. 
    • Stages of web development: Design, Coding, Development
    • Adobe XD is a powerful wireframing tool.
  • The different roles in a UX/UI development team: 
    • Front-end coder: creates the visual front end elements using HTML, CSS and JS.
    • Backend developer or programmer: integrates the user-facing elements with server-side logic.
    • Content manager: timely updates the content sections; finds and writes/rewrites text.
    • Project Manager: gathers project requirements, estimates cost, plans and controls time; motivates and managing risks.
    • Tester: tests on different types of mistakes - logical, content, design, technical, and so on.

    • Identify the colors of the color wheel.
    • Distinguish between fonts.
    • Discuss the use of icons in graphic and web design.
    • Match the graphic design jobs with the specific software used for each.
    • Compare Photoshop and Illustrator as graphic design tools.
    • Recall the design functions available in Adobe XD.

  • Lesson Summary

    • Color gives an emotional experience to the customer.
    • It only takes 90 seconds for people to make a subconscious judgement about a product and between 62% and 90% of that assessment is based on color alone.
    • RGB is an additive color mixing model used for digital graphic design projects, such as web design and online advertisements.
    • CMYK is a subtractive color mixing model used on physical surfaces, such as paper signage and packaging.
    • The color wheel shows the relationship between primary, secondary, and tertiary colors. Its colors can also be divided into warm and cool colors.
    • Typographic Hierarchy is a system for organizing font that establishes an order of importance, allowing the user to easily navigate the content.
    • The advantages of web fonts are, they are easily customizable and are supported by most browsers.
    • Ideally, icons should always have a text label.
    • The software used for creating and editing icons and other vector graphics is Adobe Illustrator.
    • Adobe Photoshop is the best software for editing photographs and raster graphics. 

  • Learning Outcomes

  • Having completed this module you will be able to:
    • Describe the UX design process.
    • Analyze user-profiles and user persona.
    • Distinguish between a customer journey and a sales funnel.
    • Identify the three phases and four stages of a sales funnel.
    • Recall the stages of Market Sophistication.
    • Summarize the seven principles of influence.
    • Recognize the age-based and gender-based influence triggers for sales.
    • Explain the concept of interest-based marketing.
    • Compare the user flows of competitor products and services.

  • Lesson Summary

  • Core principles of Human-centered design according to Donald Norman: 
    • Understand and address the core problems.
    • Be people-centred.
    • Use an activity centred system approach.
    • Use rapid iterations of prototyping and testing.
  • User ways to discover user profiles are as follows:
    • Surveys 
    • Sales and support team 
    • User reviews 
    • Web analytics
    • A customer journey map is a detailed outline of every step a lead takes to become a paying customer.
    • A typical customer Journey map is as follows: Awareness> consideration > Purchase > Retention > Advocacy

  • Lesson Summary

  • Learning Outcomes

  • Having completed this module you will be able to:
    • Explain the purpose of storyboards and moodboards.
    • Describe the process of creating storyboards and moodboards.
    • Discuss the need for sitemap & information architecture in UX design.
    • Distinguish between low and high fidelity wireframes and prototypes.
    • Outline the different methods of user testing.
    • Identify the people with whom you should share each of the deliverables during the UX design and development process.

  • Lesson Summary

    • A storyboard has a sequence of events along with interactions to present the product in a context and illustrate the user's flow.
    • A moodboard has pieces of design samples for inspiration that contain colors, typography, interactions, and UI elements.
    • The information architecture organizes the content most logically and efficiently to increase discoverability.
    • Wireframes are the cornerstone that connects research and design.
    • Prototypes are a fusion of wireframes and interaction.
    • The user testing is done by chosen individuals, who evaluate the prototype.
